												Devil May Cry 4 is an amazing hack-and-slash game that is easy to learn and hard to master. The combat system is very in depth and there is always more room for improvement, even for the greatest masters of the game. It also has many different difficulty levels that will keep you busy for HOURS. You get to play as either Nero, who has a very interesting combat system because of his grab ability, and Dante, who has a variety of weapons and fighting styles to choose from while in game, giving an indefinite number of possibilities for combos. Plus, the game is very pretty, even on the lowest graphics settings, and for a PC port, it is not that bad.Now here's the part where you yell at me for stating my opinion. My main criticisms of the game lie heavily in the story, which I honestly believe was bland and tasteless. Dante isn't the main character, but instead, it's Nero, who in my opinion, acted too much like a whiny ♥♥♥♥♥♥ (though his combat is very unique). A majority of the characters are completely one-dimensional and don't really serve any purpose other than being the damsel in distress or the power-hungry bad guy or the envious rival . I pretty much only enjoyed the parts of the story where Dante was included because at least he was cheeky in an enjoyable way. Although I liked Nero's combat style, it got old for me pretty quick. Other downsides include the camera problems (which I am pretty sure is typical for a Devil May Cry game), a lack of costumes, the hideous amount of backtracking which puts Dante's role in the game to shame (I am talking you're backtracking for almost HALF THE GAME), and the lame final boss whose attack patterns are very predictable. Plus there's not much innovation put into the level design, which brings me back to the backtracking issue. I honestly felt like I was playing a somewhat incomplete story.Overall DMC4 was a mostly fun ride from start to end. It does bring back Bloody Palace as well as has a couple fun bosses. What it fails at in areas such as level design and completeness, the game makes up for it with an awesome combat system, beautiful visuals, and long playability.Overall I give Dante May Backtrack 4 a 7/10TL;DR It's fun to play but it's half of a good game.

The Special Edition (re-release/standalone expansion) is coming out on June 24th as a separate product. If you were considering this, I suggest you wait a few months.Devil May Cry 4 is intended for a controller, playable with a keyboard (on the highest difficulties and for doing advanced combos)- but bizarre as the mouse is only for menus. In a lot of cases the game will require the player to press 3+ keys at the same time without ghosting (common in cheap keyboards made only for typing).The game still refers to a left analog stick when listing the inputs for a command, which corresponds to some action with WASD- there is no walk modifier key, and the interact [contextual] button will remain even when the command it's tied to has been rebound.The game also forces the player to play as specific characters for certain missions, while leaving some boss fights unavailable (i.e Sanctus vs Dante; The Savior vs Nero) or far less accessible (i.e Credo vs Dante after 79 waves in Bloody Palace compared to Nero who only needs to reach the end of a mission). This could also affect the general learning curve and game progression (e.g unlocks, next difficulty) if the characters are played for imbalanced amounts of time and/or the player finds a preference of which character to play.In content, it's typical for a Devil May Cry game to have some backtracking or content recycling; in this iteration, it's done quite unimaginatively in having the backtracking mission's traversal mostly be the backwards of the initial path. Another is using the same generic battle theme per character for the non-boss encounters (few exceptions).The game excels in combat and the nuances & quirks in building combos- e.g Jump Canceling, Guard Flying, Guard Cancel, Invulnerable Frames on certain actions; though at points there'll be a disconnection between what the game considers 'stylish' and what is actually technically impressive ('stylish' to other people).If you find yourself having little intention to replay or practice playing the game long enough to accomplish the more technical feats, this game, like most, may not be as satisfying as doing so.

												So i've played this game for about 40 hours or so and I think it's time to tell you guys my opinion of the game so far. I'll probably be updating this review the more i play this game, but this is my opinion so far.This game donesn't have the awesome atmosphere, enviroments and music that DMC3 had, but it's still and awesome game. The graphics are great! They still hold up 6 years after its release. The voice acting is also pretty good and the story is okay. Even though he's not as complex as Dante, he's still got a far bit of depth to his combos and relies more on timing with his EX gauge. Nero is also more accesable to new players of the series. His combos are more simple in comparison to Dante, but he still plays great. There were also some new features added to the PC version of this game, the best of these being the new difficulty, Legendary Dark Knight mode. Legendary Dark Knight mode is a great addition to the game and it's pretty addictive as well. This game will also run on a low end PC just fine , there is also alot of replay value here and if you love the DMC series, you'll find yourself sinking plenty of hours into this game. Now here comes the bad. My problems with the game would be that it doesn't feel as finished or polished as DMC3, and that's because it's not. The enviroments are kind of copy and paste (Except for the Jungle) and the music is mediocre at best. It is also alot more repetative than the previous games (I don't know about 2 because i've never played it). You fight the 4 same bosses at least 3 times in 1 playthrough and the chess sections are just so dumb. But that doesn't mean the game is bad. Overall it has great graphics, cool cutscenes and the best combat system in any game i've played. If you can get over it's minor flaws, you will have a blast experimenting with new and different combos and enjoying yourself in one of the best action games of all time.

												Lazy, spontaneous review incoming: DMC4 is a mixed bag for both longtime fans and newcommers alike, and for legit reasons. DMC4 has multiple flaws ranging from unfair enemy AI to backtracking, but at the same time offers what I think is the most complex and rewarding gameplay in the genre. Here are a few major pros and cons many have with this title:Pros-Amazing Gameplay. It doesn't take long for one to be a decent DMC4 player as its much more lenient than its prodecessors. However the meta of this game has been developing for more almost 7 years, with no sign of stopping, and if you intend to keep up with it, you'll end up crying and wishing you'd play DmC:DmC:DE instead. Combo videos and tournaments show how far the gameplay has evolved.-Cheesy DialogueThis game has cheesy one liners and story, some of it is unintentionally bad, but most of it is intentional, mostly when it comes to Dante.-Efficient Port. Seriously, this game can run on a toaster powered by Homer Simpson's brain. I ran this on an i5 with integrated graphics (HD4000) and it ran anywhere between 50-90fps at medium settings at 720p. With my new laptop, I can run it at 120fps (the game is capped at that framerate) at 1080p with everything maxed out. However, recording gameplay is strangely demanding/inconsistent. I recommend you use something like Bandicam (with Motion JPEG or another, more efficient codec) or Dxtory to record, though I assume most of you have PCs powerful enough to not notice a thing.-GraphicsSure, compared to games of today, the graphics are below average, but for its age it holds up well. Especially if you consider it ran at an average of 60fps on consoles, and should be better looking when DMC4SE comes out. A minor point as this game's strengh comes in gameplay, but still worth pointing out.Cons-BacktrackingIts horrible, about half of the game consists of backtracking. Granted, some areas have been changed significantly, and virtually all enemy waves are altered, but the same levels appear multiple times. -Nero as a Main CharacterA lot of the backlash of this game was the replacement of the series' main protagonist, Dante, with a younger character called Nero. He takes more than half of the game for himself, so might even argue most of the game since Dante backtracks Nero's missions. This is more of a con to longtime fans of the series. He's an amature and cries a lot for my liking. His gameplay is also more shallow in comparison to Dante's, but to Nero's credit, still has enough for veterans to experiment with (seriously, I play Dante much more than Nero, but I can still appreciate the skill and creativity players display with him).-Unfair EnemiesDMC4 has the best gameplay I've ever seen in the genre, but paradoxically lacks good enemies. Dont get me wrong, a good fraction of the depth should be attributed to the enemies and how their physics and AI work. But if there's one thing I hate, its unfair attack cues. Certain enemies have attacks that are downright cheap. The time between the attack animation starts to when the attack hits (the player) can last less than a second, which can be avoidable if you were doing nothing else but standing, but in a game like this, odds are that you were in the middle of an attack, in a room filled with enemies. Certain enemies like Chimeran Assualts and Chimeran Scarecrows attack the player even if they're stunned, with almost random attack patterns with no attack cues. You basically have to play it safe and use quick long ranged attacks that contribute to bordom. Unfortunately, around half of the enemies have at least one cheap attack, which is sad considering there wouldn't be any problem if it wasn't for that 1 or so attack.-StoryThe series never had a strengh in story, gameplay and style always came first. This may or may not be a good thing for you. For me it certainly didn't matter, but there are some newcomers that believe every game should be a hollywood movie. The game is arguably a downgrade in story quality, when compared to DMC3.TL;DR: If you're into stylish gameplay that will keep your attention for years, I highly recommend this game. If you intend to play this game only once, it can be hard for me to recommend you this game. Especially if you're into the CINEMATIK XPERIENZ

												I paid $5 for Devil May Cry 4 and it took around 13 hours to finish on Devil Hunter mode.  I used an Xbox 360 controller the entire time.  I wouldn't say I did great, but I still got to the end with some frustration.  I'd say I highly recommend this one.  I've never played a DMC game before.  The closest I got was X-Blades and that...wasn't really a good representative of the spectacle fighter genre or whatever it's called.  This review is probably better aimed at people new to the series like I was.  The game is a third-person action title.  Apart from solving some simple puzzles, DMC4 largely revolves around fighting groups of mooks and large bosses, often in a “room locks, kill everything to proceed” format.  Nero's gameplay involves using a mix of his gun and sword for regular combat, but he has a unique feature in his Devil Bringer arm for heavy but slow attacks or for bringing an enemy/yourself closer or to evade some attacks.  Dante's gameplay involves on-the-fly swapping between his four stances along with changing his ranged and melee weapons.  Nero's playstyle felt easy to use for a newcomer like me, and Dante felt pretty advanced though I still did fine without really using his full potential.  DMC4 is the kind of game that rewards you for learning its systems and playing well.  You're graded at the end of each mission on time taken, Style points, the percentage of Red Orbs found, and any modifying bonuses or penalties like using no items or dying and continuing.  Higher ratings give more Proud Souls which are spent to unlock new abilities or weapon combos or the like.  You can also refund spent Proud Souls to tweak or completely remake your build between missions or at the Divinity Statues scattered through the environment.  Time taken is self-explanatory, and Red Orbs are found in the world and are dropped by enemies, and these are spent at Divinity Statues for consumable recovery items or permanent boosts with no refund option.  As for Style points, one of the series' features is its high risk Style system.  By avoiding damage and attacking enemies with strings of combos, your Style meter will raise and increase in rank.  Getting hit will knock you down a couple of ranks, and using your guns to play it safe won't impress anyone.  It's a largely optional feature, but apart from the rewards mentioned above, it does feel awesome to work up to a high rank and keep it going.  There are a total of seven difficulty levels though you start with two.  For what I played being “normal” level, it was still pretty tough, though I imagine it'd be a cakewalk for veterans.  Apart from the unlockable standard hard and very hard, there are a couple of different ones where both you and the enemies die in a single hit, where only you die in a single hit and the enemies don't, or one where enemies spawn in fairly large packs as shown in some of the screenshots on the Steam Store page.  There are other things to unlock on the collectibles side, like the Gallery entries or in-game achievements, and there are Secret Missions hidden away with bonuses for those who can complete them.  Overall, I enjoyed DMC4 despite some annoyances like having to fight the camera a couple of times, or bosses that were a chore to kill.  I probably won't pick it up again anytime soon, but I left the game on a high note at least.  The game ran incredibly well on my rig in DirectX10 mode and I think I only saw less than 60 frames maybe once the entire run.  There's a lot of replay value if you like the idea of harder challenges or just want to get a better score.  This version of the game tends to be cheaper than the Special Edition, though that obviously has more content and features in its favor.

Devil May Cry 4 is an action hack and slash fantasy game. It is renowned as quite challenging (with solid AI and bunch of difficulties), therefore, a simple button mashing won't be beneficial. In addition to fighting, there are also some puzzles to solve and a good plot to enjoy:Story itself is a sequel to Devil May Cry 3 but fully understandable even if you didn't play previous games. Summary of the story in one sentence: Nero goes out on a hunt to kill Dante, a half demon who's presumably a murderer, just to find out who's the real threat to mankind. It has a little bit of everything: action, drama and comedy, thus, making it a really enjoyable ride.During the playthrough you get to play as both Dante (easygoing, sarcastic and calm guy) and Nero (impetuous and naive kid). They have a decent weapon arsenal and skill diversity but plays similarly. The character swap happens as you progress halfway through the story but the main issue here is that as soon as you get to play as Dante you must complete the same path that Nero did. Only backwards with few additions here and there. This turns into a bigger problem when you have to kill the same boss for the third time throughout the game. It shows laziness and lack of creativity from developers. Another thing that I really loved is that demons (especially bosses) have a very unique design and differ in their abilities. Accordingly, you're bound to adapt and learn how to deal with them.The biggest disappointments for me were controls, the menu and the most of all, absurd camera angles. These problems greatly reduced my enjoyment while playing but nevertheless the positive aspects strongly outweigh the negatives and I'd recommend this game to everyone.7/10

Posted: February 25, 2014
												With it's fluid combat mechanics, astounding character models, and level and enemy variety, it's hard to see why Devil May Cry 4 has been overlooked and underrated. The game allows you to take on the role of Nero, and later Dante, the latter being the main protagonist of the series, having more weapons, however in DMC4, you are playing the role of Nero instead, who has comparitevly less weapons and movesets. The story of DMC4 unfortunately is not there. Although lengthy at around 12 hours, you will find yourself stuck in a cliche of Nero's love interest being snatched away, and he must rescue her (Mario I'm looking at you). You'll hack, slash, and shoot your way through hordes of varied enemies, across semi - linear levels. The latter part of the campaign however, is where you might see it getting repetitive, with you playing the story essentially in reverse order, but this time as Dante. Aside from the story, something that DMC4 does do right (and in my opinion, makes it worth getting), is the combat system. As mentioned before, fighting in DMC4 is like no other, and is smooth as butter. Both Nero and Dante are equipped with 2 categories of weapons: ranged and Melee. Nero having a double barreled revolver named Blue Rose, and a motorcycle engine sword, Red Queen. While this may seem little, each weapons has its own unique moves, and can be executed using combos on the keyboard. These moves can be linked with a little practice (I recommend learning how to Jump Cancel first), and can make for a very fun time. If that's not enough, Nero also has a special melee/pseudo ranged weapon named the Devil Bringer, allowing you to smash enemies into the ground WWE style, drag enemies closer to you, and pull off various high damaging finisher moves. On the other end of the spectrum, Dante is the one with the absurd amount of weapons, ranging from his signature pistols Ebony and Ivory, to a transformable suitcase called Pandora. What's more is that Dante has various styles to choose from, ranging from Gunslinger, to Sword Master, Royal Guard, and Trickster. Each has its own unique abilities to manipulate certain weapons. Gunslinger allows free play of Dante's ranged weapons, such as and aerial spinning top move with his pistols, rapid firing his shotgun Coyote-S, or adding new forms to Pandora. Sword Master allows Dante to perform special moves regarding his sword, Rebellion, his rocket-fist Giglamesh, and the explosive spear dealer, Lucifer. Royal Guard allows Dante to heavily mitigate damage from enemies, building up his rage bar, and eventually allowing him to release devastating counter attacks, and even transform into an invicible armor. Finally, Trickster allows Dante to move faster, short range teleport, and perform other stylish moves to better evade, and gain a position on enemies. All of these styles can be switched on the fly with no delay (unless you're standing still), and can be employed very effectively. All of this combat is rated by an in game on the fly letter grade system, ranging from a D-SSS. Overall, get DMC4 if you enjoy hack n' slash games with fluid combat, but prepare to be dissapointed should you buy it for the story. P.S.: For those who are wondering, there is indeed a "endless combat" mode, deemed Bloody Palace. While not exactly endless, its 101 floors will provide plenty of challenge and replayability.

												Devil May Cry 4 is an ambitious, unfinished sequel that doesn't really have a hope in hell of improving as a whole upon what are considered it's true predecessors. That being said, it's still a decent game, but it just doesn't have the charm, the love of 3 or 1. Dante just feels a little bit emptier than before, and that goes for his dialogue and gameplay as well. Yes, style switching is really really cool! It's super fun, and when you get the hang of it everything just feels like one big sychronised movement. But in the end, the enemies feel like they aren't made for Dante, and downgrading his moveset to balance it out is kind of a cop out, I understand it's Dante, who never really puts his all into it and just plays for fun, but I just can't get behind the "DT upgrading style moves" thing at all. On top of that, Lucifer usually just feels like a placeholder for show, with no real substance to it, but I can say having the three guns is cool. All in all, the mainstay's gameplay is good, not as great as 3 Dante, but good.Now, when we get to Nero, I think he's actually solid as well, but I have to get something out of the way first. First half of the game with him(Takes me like 2:30 with S ranks, I think it's more around 3-4 hours for the real first time) is always painful, but you can lessen the burden if you level yourself in a fashion that allows you to really get in the flow of Nero, stuff like Snatch, Charge Shot, Streak, Split, Air Hike, and Enemy Hike are must haves for the first playthrough(MaxACT, Exceed 2, Exceed 3, and Calibur aren't really feasible to obtain first playthrough without replaying levels or the dreaded return to Nero level) That being sad, his more air based flowchart gameplay isn't bad at all, and you can certainly get creative with the character. What isn't creative is his writing, you have a 30/70 chance of a good cutscene with this kid, really. And by good cutscenes, I mean the DMC3 Dante attitude showing in Nero, with the twist of his abilities. Often times, it's KYRIEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE, showing that Devil May Cry 4 should've been named Devil Will Cry A Lot. Another issue is that Nero feels like he's as unfinished as the Dante backtrack, some of the enviroments, and the fact there aren't any actual alterations as far as I know to the levels they both share. Imagine how Nero would be if HE had buster styles? Buster style switching? There are so many things you can do with a giant blue hand, but Capcom would rather the game release with Nero just using it for masturbation, I suppose.Not only that, but the story feels like a rerun of 3 in a lot of ways and it also hints at a sequel which you know was only because they really really wanted to make more and expand on it, because clearly they weren't satisfied with the time they had. It's a cool game, and it's worth a buy, but it's nowhere near the pinnacle of the series.

												First off, this version of the game has been made obselete by the Special Edition, which has more playable characters, a couple new modes and more content for your buck. That said, I happened to buy this before the Special Edition came out...and I'm actually surprised that they released an updated version of this game in 2015, because some parts of it are dated as hell. All the standard tropes of PS2-era Japanese action games are on full display, ranging from fixed camera angles, obscenely annoying special missions, arbitrary puzzles (this was always Devil May Cry's schtick though) and a story that's like reaaaaaallly anime, and not in a great way (also Devil May Cry's schtick, with the exception of the third game). But the actual meat and potatoes of DMC4, the stylish combat, is still really good. You've got a crapload of weapons, including my favorite - the Pandora, a transformable suitcase that changes into 666 different types of gun - and switching between Dante's styles or using Nero's devil arm on the fly to throw foes is grand. Only thing is, I would've liked the game more if it had just starred Dante, especially because Dante's levels are a backtracking paltry amount compared to Nero's. Nero reminds me too much of a Final Fantasy protagonist, and part of the joy of DMC is watching Dante take the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of everything because he knows he's an outrageous demon hunter. Nero just doesn't have that flamboyance, and I get that he was created to draw new players into the series, but because his design is so similar to Dante, you can't help but compare the two. Dante always comes out on top...so it's like, what was the point of putting Nero in there at all?Anyway, still a solid game, though DMC3 remains the king of the pre-reboot titles.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												So I've been a long time fan of Devil May Cry, and I'm probably the only person I know that is. I picked up the first game around the time it came out and died terribly all the way to the second or third-to-last mission, and then I was stuck there for a while. I eventually finished the game, and I stayed a fan of the original even after playing through 2 (note: it's bad...really really bad), and became a bigger fan after playing 3 (my favorite so far). Oddly, 2, 3, and 4 were all directed by the same person, Hideaki Itsuno, though 2 was very different from the rest of the series. After 3 I was definitely willing to give it a go again, so I was very excited when 4 came out. Here I am FINALLY playing it in 2014, almost 6 years after the game came out in 2008, and I thought I'd write up what I thought of the game overall.StoryIn Devil May Cry 4 you play as Nero instead of Dante. Nero is another white-haired sword-wielding Devil Hunter like Dante, but he's younger, likely around Dante's age in 3 which was a prequel. You start out the game with a scene that looks like it came right out of Spider-Man 2 where Nero's on his way to see a girl on stage and gets interrupted by demons. He manages to make it there as the performance ends, and the girl is so happy to see him that there's no real conflict that arrises from it.Nero acts really aloof and stand-offish right away which makes him seem really unlikable, and even whiny. Shortly, though, Dante shows up guns blazing and Nero rises to the challenge of trying to fend him off while everyone else is running around in a panic. From then on Nero seems more and more like Dante himself. Starting with the scene where he's given his sword, and going on to each major demon he faces, Nero keeps up with the wise-cracks Dante is known and loved for, and I actually really ended up liking him as a character as the game went on.Halfway through the game you actually end up playing as Dante for a few missions. There's a lot of fan service here with Dante showing off in every cut scene he's in, with a bunch of silly over-the-top scenes evey time he gets a hold of a new weapon. There's a particularly funny moment when he and one of the villains act like they're in a play when they meet to fight on a stage.Overall I thought the story and characters were well written with the exception of Kyrie, the love interest. Kyrie is the classic damsel-in-distress and you never really learn much about her because she's always either captured and hidden offscreen or oddly mute. The actual plot surrounds a group of people wanting to use Sparda's power to become gods and take over the world which is somewhat similar to the main villain's goal in 3, but there's a little more going on here with more exposition and more characters.DesignThe world design and character design is very similar to the previous games. There are gothic ruins and a city that seems to have a Vatican City vibe to it, as well as a jungle (oddly enough). Characters look similar to what you'd see in 1 and 3, though Dante is sporting a goatee now and a set of boots that look like they may be a little too big. Every female character seems to have spontaneously become extremely well-endowed for some reason, including a couple of returning characters.Creature designs in this game are the best in the series in my opinion. One of the bosses is a giant frog with two lures similar to an angler fish, but the lures are shaped like human women. My favorite design is the Blitz which is a blind demon that uses lightning.The weapon designs are interesting, the two most interesting and ridiculous being Pandora and Lucifer. Pandora is a demonic suitcase that can transform into multiple different guns including a ridable missile platform; yes, I'm serious. Lucifer is a very strange shoulder-mounted weapon that looks like a demon head with bat-like wing/arms. Lucifer allows Dante to create blades that explode a while after being stabbed into enemies, and he can throw the rose he holds in his teeth to manually detonate all of the blades at once; again I'm not making this up.GameplayThe gameplay in Devil May Cry 4 is similar in feel to the rest of the series. Nero has almost the same moveset that Dante does for his standard sword with a few differences. The ability that replace Stinger has an area of effect when it lands, for instance. Nero also gets an ability that gives feedback when there are secrets nearby which is absent when you play as Dante.Nero has two new special abilities that change up combat a little bit. The first is his Devil Bringer which is his demonic right arm. The Devil Bringer allows Nero to pull enemies towards him and perform special grab attacks when their guard is down. This mechanic is easily my favorite addition to combat in this game.Nero's second ability is the EX Gauge which the player has to rev up like an engine to perform more powerful attacks with the sword. I found this ability to be lacking because the extra time taken to charge attacks up didn't seem worth the little bit of extra damage you supposedly got from it. I got into trouble more often than not when using this ability either while revving it up or by missing my charged up attacks.Dante's gameplay is similar to Nero's but it drops the two extra abilities I mentioned previously. Instead of the Devil Bringer grab system Dante gets access to the Style system from 3. This allows him to switch through a larger moveset for swordplay or guns, the Royal Guard style that adds a guard system that gathers energy from blocked attacks into an attack Dante can use against enemies, and the Trickster style that increases movement.Dante gets access to more weapons than Nero, filling in the standard Devil Arm quotient for the game. Overall Dante is the more versitile character, and it feels a little jarring to get used to Nero's fighting style that focuses heavily on the grab-and-throw Devil Bringer, then change to Dante's extended moveset which drops the grab system entirely, and then back again.To unlock new abilities in this game you use proud souls instead of red orbs like in previous games. Red orbs are still in the game and used as currency for items in the shop, and red orbs are still awarded from every enemy defeated and found floating around in missions. Proud souls are only awarded at the end of a mission. A convenient feature is the ability to unpurchase any ability any time you're in the shop which allows you to change your loadout between fights or missions if you would like to try out different abilities.Devil Trigger is available after a few missions, and it is basically the same as usual. Nero gets a couple of extra moves to use.Secret missions return in the game, and remain, in my opinion, uninteresting. They are usually very difficult to complete and give a reward of a blue orb fragment. Occasionally you will come across a secret mission as Nero or Dante that can only be completed by the other character. The game doesn't let you know this is the case, and you have to learn it on your own which can be a little bit annoying.The difficulty curve in this game is high, like the others. There's a point when you have to fight Dante as Nero that took me 2 hours of tries to complete on Devil Hunter difficulty. There's also a couple of strange sections where you roll a die to move yourself around a gameboard to continue on, and because of the randomness of the die this is easily frusterating, especially at the end of the game. There's also a few times where it's hard to figure out exactly what the game wants you to do, but overall I was happy with the gameplay.Final ThoughtsOverall I really liked this game, and I would recommend it to anyone that would like to try it out. Currently in the series I am ranking 3 at the top, trailed closely by 4, with 1 at the bottom. 2 doesn't get to be on the ranking.

Posted: January 30, 2014
												The initial impression of the PC edition of Devil May Cry 4 was a bit disconcerting. Sure, the visuals are breathtaking in high resolution, both throughout gameplay and during the well-directed cut-scenes. You're going to get a kick out of the atmosphere, especially if you're playing the DX10 version. The music, sound effects and voice-overs are top-notch, so no problems there either. The instant disappointment arrived when I tried to maneuver the main character via the awkward keyboard controls.The controls can be adjusted, though I'm afraid this won't help you much. You use the WASD keys for movement, while various actions and attacks are pulled off by pressing a variety of keys with your right hand. As a result, performing combos and stunts proved extremely difficult and to make things worse, they've completely excluded the mouse. Veteran PC gamers won't be too happy about this. To cut a long story short, if you're going to play this game, bring along a gamepad, preferably the X360 controller or one that's similar.Another huge concern is the camera. Frequently throughout the game players just aren't given the best angle to view the situation. There are many sections in the game where you cannot see where the hero needs to jump or where his enemies are. It can be a serious obstacle more often than not.The level designers did a good job of throwing enough challenges Nero's way (and Dante's, of course), although they clearly didn't think about varying things a little, since there are plenty of areas where players are forced to retrace their steps in order to progress.Somehow, even with the faulty controls, this game succeeds in reeling you in with its captivating graphics, stunning artwork and brilliantly designed monsters and characters. The story is, well, baffling to say the least.Trying to decipher what the writers wanted to say may take you forever (a common symptom in Japanese games, yes). Still, the overall presentation is excellent and makes up for the confusing narrative.The well-balanced character powers -- plus, plenty of combos and different melee and ranged attacks -- are the reason Devil May Cry 4 is so addictive. If you're stuck in a certain area, getting through a lengthy platform-jumping sequence or if you're fighting a tough boss battle, it's constant fun and a great challenge. To spice things up for PC owners, the developers fitted on a spanking new "Legendary Dark Knight" mode, offering you a chance to slice more opponents than ever before and increasing the challenge further. This is a fine element, but when it comes to PC extras, we kind of expected more from Capcom - essentially, more content, a new chapter in the story, more secret levels and similar things.Devil May Cry 4 is a good game if you're prepared to overlook certain downsides - first and foremost, the controls and camera. Next up, there's a solid amount of backtracking and there are a few recurring boss fights. Even so, the game is well-polished and it certainly looks sharper and better than on the console editions. What's more, it should appeal to fans and newbies alike.

												Well, I know that many have reviewed and have said their fair share about this game, but I guess I will share what I feel others should know if there were to think about buying this game. Do I think this game is a good game: Yes, I do. I don't think its the holy grail of the DMC series (not counting the reboot here since I havnt played it as of yet.) But I do find it a great addition to the series. It took me a while to play it merely due to time, but as a vetren of the series of old, I would say that I did enjoy it.How did this game compare to the others: I would say that it would be ranked 2nd out of the 4 main series in my opinion. It is a close first for sure, but there are minor details that just draw it away a little. I havn't gotten a chance to play the Special edition, but this one just did things that went CRAZY! For one, I like the addition of Nero, I did have fun playing as him, and after upgrading alot, loved his devil arm. But I did not have fun with his lack of 'power'. When I say power for Nero, I mean, you remove that devil arm of his and he loses alot of skill. And when you play as Dante for the later half, you realize just how much you rely on that thing for all of his moves or power. Thats not a bad thing, but I feel they could have done a little bit more skills with it besides something like "hold" which just allows you to hold an enemy. Maybe something like combing it with your gun or the Yamato more often. Say for example they included an ability that allowed Nero to use his devil arm to grip to the walls, allowing you to be more strategic but perhaps allowing for more skills or combos with it. Dante isnt perfect either though. I love that they allowed all four styles this time around. It was so releaving having those so I could switch from the four at will, instead of having to decide what to use before each mission. His weapons were...okay. I did like to use them, but...some were just more common used from me then others. Lucifer could have been improved more, and Pandora needed to be downgraded to me. 												[Pay no heed to this play time. Trust me, I've played a lot more than what's shown.]While not quite reaching the perfection of DMC3, DMC4 still stands as one of the best of the genre. The tight gameplay, great music and unforgettable characters make this game very worthwhile to pick up if you're a fan of the genre.First off, this game looks gorgeous. The environments are very beautiful, and the setpieces are marvelous. The characters themselves look very good, even though they don't actually look too realistic. For a 6 year old game, the visuals definitely still hold up to this date. Also, this game can run perfectly even on mid-range rigs (my 820m could run it at a smooth 60fps all the way, although at 720p).The gameplay is what really makes this game shine. The controls are very tight, whether you're playing on a gamepad or with a keyboard (gamepad is infinitely better, but keyboard is still great if you're used to it. If you're not, it won't take long to get a grip on the controls, trust me). You never really feel like deaths happen on the game's end, and not on yours. While hacking your way through the smaller enemies is great, the bosses is where this game is at its best. Recognising their patterns and acting accordingly is what it's all about, and it feels seriously good if you manage to pull it off. The gameplay distinction between Nero and Dante is also very good. Both have upsides and downsides, and I can't really choose favourites. Dante is so fun because of his different weapons and styles, and Nero is so much fun because of his Devil Bringer, and the many uses it brings with it. Who you'll like more is all up to you to decide.The only real downside is how Dante's side of the story is a literal backtrack of Nero's story, down to fighting the exact same bosses. This bogs it down quite a bit, as there is a lot of missed potential here. However, fighting these bosses again with a different playstyle does feel fun and refreshing, so that makes up for it a bit. All in all, this game is seriously great. Learning it may be easy and quick, but mastering it to get to the higher difficulties is very difficult and very fun. Pick it up if you like these games. You won't regret it. At all.

												I don't even know how to get started with this game.The story is totally cheesy over the top madness. You play as two demon hunters and guess what? You fight demons and save the world, big surprise. The story is narrated through unbelieveable cutscenes, where the characters get impaled and yet survive, do impossible stuff like deflecting bullets with other bullets, punch a giant stone wall into smithereens, transform a suitcase in a gunship and so on. Big explosions, action and stuff spiced up with crazy music. I was laughing hard during most of these cutscenes. The characters are totally crazy and over the top. There's this guy who wears a red coat and cowboy boots, who would get laughed out of any bar, that's totally crazy. The word is about to be destroyed and he acts all cocky and makes fun of his enemies. The dumbest hilarious cutscene involves him drawing a heart in a hell gate with blade-mines and then make it go boom, while flamenco music plays.The music is terrific, loud and sang with a weird growling voice. The lyrics are beyond redemption and listening to some tracks would make any normal human being flee in terror, and its speed it's well known for causing tachycardia.The gameplay is totally unrealistic. You have these two guys who wield swords as tall as they are and shoot unlimited bullets out of oversized guns. You can do physics defying stuff like launch an enemy in the air, follow it, swing your sword at it a few times, then hover on it showering it with bullets, then hit it some more, then kick its face a few times, plant a few blade-mines on it, then pull out a katana and slash it, then land in a crowd of enemies punching the ground causing an explosion and flip your shotgun at them like a nunchaku while shooting. On top of it, the action is so fast you can't really understand what's going on unless you're pro or someting.There's this kid that's like the sheer power character. He can "act" his sword to make it ignite and spinning through the screen covered in fire, charge up gun shots to make groups of enemies explode and has the ability to execute high damaging grapples on foes. Than there's this other guys that has five "styles" that you can switch on the fly and every stile changes the function of your "style button" according to your equipped weapon. And speaking of weapons oh boy, this guy is a walking army, he has 3 melee weapons and 3 ranged ones and one of them has 4 normal firing modes. All of this stuff makes this guy incredibly complex to use. I mean, who needs all that variety? The combat system let's you pull out some infuriatingly complex combos if you are skilled enough but who cares?! Why can't I just spam Y and get SSS ranking?!Every mission gives you a rank, that is a combination of diferent factors. I hear crazy fans actually play to best each other scores, while I can barely survive.There's a lot of enemy variety, and some of them require special mechanics to be defeated or are generally better dealt with with specific tactics, forcing you to think fast and pick your target carefully. Who the hell wants to think when playing a game?!Did I mention that the game is incredibly hard? Because it is. If you never played an hack&slash you could even die on the second level boss! What madness is this? And, once you complete the game, you can start all over INCREASING THE DIFFICULTY! Who in their right state of mind would make things even more challenging than they already are?! Also, you unlock a game mode that essentially is a restless battle, not even one single platform section!Did I say the game had 2 harder difficulty modes? Sorry I meant 3, because the PC version pushes things even further with a mode where you fight an INSANE amount of enemies, like the ones you fight in Human mode weren't enough. Also, to make things even more frantic and hard, PC version adds  turbo mode that makes everything run faster. Unbelievable.So, for all of these reasons, I declare this thing one of the best games ever made. Played back then on my deceased ps3, still playing it today on pc, listening to its amazing songs, enjoying its hilarious characters and having fun with the new game mode and the turbo function the excellent PC port provides. Too bad they couldn't finish the game properly but I think that just the Bloody Palace is more then enough to justify the price tag. It aged well... actually, it doesn't feel the age at all, it's waaay better than 99% of the crap we get today.

												I barely recommend it at $5 or less. 14 hours of gameplay accumulated. Steam didn't track all of it.I'm a big fan of DMC3 and I mildly enjoyed the original. I feel like this project completely missed the mark in almost every possible way. I was extremely warm on it for the first few hours but it quickly wore out it's welcome.Now, it's visually stunning, and the PC port is flawless and enhanced. That's just dandy. But the mechanics in this game just do nothing for me. I can't stand playing as either Nero or Dante here. It just doesn't quite feel right, and many of the new moves and weaponry just seem like half-baked♥♥♥♥♥♥they chucked at a wall to see what would stick. Very little of it does.I didn't give half a care about the story from start to finish, and I ended up just uninstalling the game at the 2nd to the last boss and watching the ending online. The cutscenes are completely mind-numbing and over-the-top in ways I never thought imaginable, this side of the Metal Gear Solid remake Twin Snakes. They don't seem to realize that the stupidity of DMC3 was charming, but you can't just make it twice as stupid and expect it to be twice as entertaining. Every ounce of this story, dialog, and even motion capture and character body language is painfully annoying. I cringed for hours upon hours watching this game unfold. I can only assume this is yet another case of lost in translation, but I've never seen an entire cast of characters say so many words without telling me ANYTHING. Japan. Just stop.I would suggest you only play on the easiest difficulty and blast through it on automatic mode as a button masher. It's not at all worth learning how to properly play the game. I don't care about the combo system at all, and it becomes essential to beating most bosses without cheaping your way past them with health items. I only ever beat one challenge stage, for this reason. I will never understand how someone can stay airborn for 30 seconds in a DMC game, and frankly, I shouldnt have to learn. I should just be able to enjoy the game to completion.I'm eager to move onto the DmC reboot. At least it looks like it's more tuned in on an English audience and typically when a fanbase hates an entry to a series I'm sick of, it means I'll end up liking it for it's fresh ideas.

												There isn't a whole lot to be said that hasn't already been said. This game is good. Really good. It's a hack and slash that bases itself in ridiculousness. There are more ways to take out your foes than French restaurants have ways to say, "Your taste in wine is atrocious." Excellent combat, great soundtrack. The cutscenes are actually enjoyable to watch and are not prerendered; They use the in-game engine, which is as detailed as it is colorful, a refreshing change of pace from other games of its generation. In terms of port quality, it's beautiful. Even on my absolute toaster of a computer, the game manages to stay at around 85 frames per second, even when the screen is crowded with baddies with the PC exclusive Legendary Dark Knight difficulty. The keyboard controls won't do you well, however. I'd recommend getting an Xbox 360 controller, which is nearly perfect, except for two points I'll get to later.The game has a ton of replay value. Aside from Bloody Palace, there are a plethora of unlockable moves, difficulties, and artwork/biographies, but I have to note that the latter is stuff that anyone can find in a quick search on Google. Really, the most rewarding part of this game is the game itself, and overcoming the increasing challenges it throws at you by practicing and mastering the combat. Even after beating everything the game keeps track of with an S rating, I still don't feel like I'm as good at it as I could be, and this is a welcome feeling to have.Cons: Aside from fewer style moves than in DMC 3, the biggest issues I noted were- The camera. It gets stuck on scenery and can get jammed into places that make it impossible to see what you're doing (especially during boss battles). The targeting is also a pain. It seems that no matter which of the targeting modes I choose, I can never lock on to the enemy I want. When the camera and targeting issues combine, combat feels much harder than it should be.-The length. The various difficulty options are a blast, but the core game is just too short. 20 missions, okay, but 3 of them are only boss battles. Dante is fun to play as, but he only gets 7 missions, and most of them are backtracking. The one unique boss fight he gets is its own level and can be completed in about 10 minutes. It feels like two halves of a game are slapped together here, with Nero missing a big chunk of missions and Dante not having much of an opportunity to show off his insanely large moveset.- The controller. I know, I know, it's not really a criticism of the game, but I know that most people are going to be using an Xbox 360 controller with this, and while it is the best of the controllers I tried, it has issues which negatively show in the game. The D-pad is horrid, it makes instant style switching with Dante touchy to the point that combos will be screwed up. Nero is another problem. I found myself doing "the claw" with my right hand many times during combat, as I was charging the exceed meter, charging the gun, adjusting the camera, and dodging attacks at the same time. Changing the controls only helps so much; There is simply too much going on at one time for the few amount of buttons on the controller.It's pretty fun, and this is where I'd crack a joke about it being like Dark Souls with less anime, but it's interesting I should bring up Dark Souls, because...I got this just before DMC 4 Special Edition was announced, which is set to come out this summer, and is going to be offered as its own thing. If you pay for this version now, you're not getting the full deal which comes out in a matter of months. As such, I have to strongly suggest just waiting for SE.

Posted: March 21, 2015
												Devil May Cry 4 is an amazing hack-and-slash game that is easy to learn and hard to master. The combat system is very in depth and there is always more room for improvement, even for the greatest masters of the game. It also has many different difficulty levels that will keep you busy for HOURS. You get to play as either Nero, who has a very interesting combat system because of his grab ability, and Dante, who has a variety of weapons and fighting styles to choose from while in game, giving an indefinite number of possibilities for combos. Plus, the game is very pretty, even on the lowest graphics settings, and for a PC port, it is not that bad.Now here's the part where you yell at me for stating my opinion. My main criticisms of the game lie heavily in the story, which I honestly believe was bland and tasteless. Dante isn't the main character, but instead, it's Nero, who in my opinion, acted too much like a whiny ♥♥♥♥♥♥ (though his combat is very unique). A majority of the characters are completely one-dimensional and don't really serve any purpose other than being the damsel in distress or the power-hungry bad guy or the envious rival . I pretty much only enjoyed the parts of the story where Dante was included because at least he was cheeky in an enjoyable way. Although I liked Nero's combat style, it got old for me pretty quick. Other downsides include the camera problems (which I am pretty sure is typical for a Devil May Cry game), a lack of costumes, the hideous amount of backtracking which puts Dante's role in the game to shame (I am talking you're backtracking for almost HALF THE GAME), and the lame final boss whose attack patterns are very predictable. Plus there's not much innovation put into the level design, which brings me back to the backtracking issue. I honestly felt like I was playing a somewhat incomplete story.Overall DMC4 was a mostly fun ride from start to end. It does bring back Bloody Palace as well as has a couple fun bosses. What it fails at in areas such as level design and completeness, the game makes up for it with an awesome combat system, beautiful visuals, and long playability. It wasn't as good as Devil May Cry 3, but better than DmC Devil May Cry.Overall I give Dante May Backtrack 4 an 8/10TL;DR The gameplay is amazing, but the story was very lackluster and unfinished

												A short rundown of the game: Default controls suck, works great on my machine.Currently, I'm running Linux so this review is from memory. This is also my first ACTUAL review.Personally, I give this game an 8/10 with the following reasons:Good charactersFun bossesDecent graphicsDante's weapons. Need I say more?Nero's screaming for KyrieAlright, so playing this game my first order of business was to edit the controls. Normally, people complain about the controls of every single game that was created for the console and put on a PC; this game was very simple for adjusting controls, but really wanted you to work for it when it came to playing. I could go on about the controls in the game, but let me say this: I got to a point where the way I adjusted my controls made the game better than what it was AFTER I got my PS3 controller to play it with. Yep. I made the game better on the Keyboard than on the Controller. In Dark Souls, that'd be IMPOSSIBLE; in this game, it's pretty easy. This game earns a 10/10 for controls on that alone.Now, not to spoil the game with the story of it, I'm only going on the gameplay aspect; you want the story, use google. I played this game entirely for the gameplay. Nero is pretty simple to control, but if you're using an older machine, you're going to have serious problems. The lag extremely effects how well you react; most times you can simply press a button when a game a local-based lags on your computer and it will slowly move. In DMC4, if you press anything, the lag actually makes the game ignore your command entirely. Backwards compatibility, I label this a 4/10.The biggest problem I had with this game is that Nero has limited weapons but does 3x as much damage as Dante, so killing as Dante takes a long time. Also, if you're new to the game, Dante will make you cry when you're fighting against him; this is coming from a guy who beat Heaven and Hell mode on DMC3 once. Dante will actually gain ALL of his weapons after you beat the game once; and believe me, he'll use them against you on the first stage of your next game. Dante also has a tendency to avoid whatever you throw at him unless you force him on the offensive and dodge his attacks yourself. Even then, he's faster than Nero, so good luck. And on your second playthrough, the first level turns out to be a major challenge. I didn't bother with Heaven or Hell mode for this exact reason. 3/10 on difficultyAfter level 1, the game is pretty enjoyable so long as you play as Nero. However, when you switch to Dante, everything becomes a major challenge. The lag becomes real, damaging enemies becomes tedious and to replace the cool minigames Nero had, Dante has immediate danger and headache inducing puzzles 24/7; in one level, all areas that were connected are redone to have portals replace the connections between them. Basically, you're going to go through a new maze a la Silph Co. teleporters. Oh, but these aren't exactly connected to each other; you can go into one and then decide to backtrack and come out of a totally different portal then the one you walked through. If you're like me and get busy playing games, this is a struggle.The game has a random scene with nothing but inuendos for no apparent reason whatsoever.Aside from that, this game was good. I don't like to praise good games or attack bad games, more show a contrary side to my own opinion. If you want my controls, message me. They worked exceptionally.

												[Edit: Commenters have brought it to my attention that my complaints regarding the controls are only applicable to the first half of the game. If you spend several hours pushing past the cumbersome nature of Nero's controls then a more versatile control scheme will eventually be made available.]My complaints regarding DMC4 would probably be numerous if I played it more, but as it stands there is only a very, very big one.There are unused controller buttons and yet they didn't see fit to assign one to a dedicated dodge. Dodging requires three parts of input: simultaneously lock on to a target, press sideways on the thumbstick (never forward or backward, thus limiting the locations you can dodge to), and press the jump button. If you can do this all at exactly the same time you will then dodge relative to the target you locked onto, and not the fixed-place camera, making it even more unwieldy. This absolutely baffling design decision made the game too frustrating for me to persevere with.I appreciate that Devil May Cry is a hardcore title for hardcore gamers with hardcore skillz in hardcore places, but turning something as elementary as dodge into a ♥♥♥♥ing combo move is just beyond the pale. I'm surprised they didn't turn jump into some crap involving three rotations of the thumbstick while chanting Hare Krishna.

												UPDATE:There is a Special Edition of the game available for purchase. It does not add too much to the PC version, however I reccomend picking that up if you have: A) Not played the game or B) Only played the 360 or PS3 versions of the game as there are a lot more modes and characters. If you have played the PC version, the only difference is the slight graphical upgrade and the new characters. Otherwise, there isn't that much of a difference between the two. It is not a MASSIVE upgrade compared to Dark Souls 2: Scholar of the First Sin, however it is worth buying if you haven't already purchased the PC version of DMC4, which I would imagine you haven't if you are reading this review.________________________________________________________________The game is absolutely amazing. This is definitely a Devil May Cry game. If you enjoyed 1 and 3, you will like this one just as much. Even if you didn't enjoy the other DMC games, you should still give this a try, whether it be because of the games being too hard, the simple control scheme, the fixed camera or the backtracking, this game improves on all of those making it a good game to start with or play even if you didn't enjoy the classic DMC games. For those who haven't played a DMC game, they are hardcore action games notorious for their difficulty. You fight demons throughout the whole games and you also fight bosses and solve puzzles. The combat is very solid, responsive, satisfying and is also very challenging to master. However being able to master the games mechanics will cause some absolutely beautiful combos and moves that your character will do which will look awesome. The games are also known for playing heavy metal music during the fight scenes and also some fairly irritating backtracking, which thankfully, has been toned down a lot in this game. The PC port is okay. The game works fairly well with keyboard and mouse (despite lack of camera control with the mouse) but the game works better with a controller. Not just because the mouse control doesn't work, but because games from this genre are just better off being played with a controller. The PC version doesn't include any overintensive features so it is also very easy to run on any machine with a high frame rate. While not the best looking game in the world, it still has enough PC specific features. There is also a Directx 10 mode. However, at least for me, this seemed to make the game a bit more unstable causing it to crash more. There also didn't appear to be that much of a difference between DX9 and DX10 modes. The PC version also has a mode which was not included on the PS3 and 360 versions due to power restraints - Legendary dark knight mode which spawns way more enemies on screen. This makes the game a lot more frantic and enjoyable and could maybe also appeal to fans of the Dynasty Warriors franchise. (Update - This mode is also included in the Special Edition of the game and may also be included on the console versions of the Special Edition)The game fixes a lot of problems that the original games have and makes the combat a lot better. It is  a little slow paced and clunky at first and the game is by no means as brutally challenging as DMC1 and 3, but it is still good. Also, your first playthrough may take you some time as you do have a few annoying puzzle sections and a few moments where you may be unsure of where to go, however it is all easy to remember so your second playthrough will be a breeze (in terms of the travelling). However, the game still has it's problems. The level design is a bit weak. The second half of the game is just all of the levels you have played through in reverse with no puzzles included. You even replay the same bosses but in reverse order. Also, for 2/3rds of the game you don't play as Dante. You play as Dante for the second half of the game and only the second half unfortunately. You cannot go back to previous levels and play as Dante which is dissapointing. However it does make the game much more enjoyable when Dante is finally playable. That may sound annoying for die-hard fans of DMC, however Nero, Dante's replacement is still fun to use, even though he feels a little slow and basic at first. Even though the level design is a little weak, that does not by any means the game is not fun to replay. It is just as fun to replay as the 3rd game. As for difficulty, easy mode is like Devil May Cry 2, however Dante must die (very hard) mode is comparable to Devil May Cry 3 on harder difficulties which, in my opinion, is spot on how they should have done the difficulty. I like this because experts get their challenge, however the game is also noob friendly. This DMC game is a good one to start with, actually as it is not so forgiving. The combat isn't amazing at first, but once you start unlocking upgrades and slowly get better, the combat begins to get amazing. Overall, DMC4 is a brilliant and worthwhile entry to the series. Despite not playing as Dante, the core is still DMC. Some could argue the combat is not as good as DMC3, however in some ways 4 is more enjoyable as it is not so brutally hard. It also does not include as much backtracking or mapless wandering around like in 3. Even if you didn't like DMC 1 or 3, you should still give this one a whirl as it might be more your thing in terms of difficulty, mechanics and level design. If you are a hardcore DMC fan, you should also give this a go, but don't expect it to be too much better than the original games.

												Probably one of the better hack and slash games out there. Definately worth the price. The music is generally good, the fighting music doesn't get old that fast (which I thought it would) and despite hearing it dozens of times throughout a level I kind of like it. Hell even the music in the menus is good. 9/10 (could be more variety but still awesome).The graphics are good as well, I noticed nothing in particular that was that bad. 10/10The gameplay is pretty solid, you have guns that do nothing in terms of damage but at least you have something to do while the enemy is trying to get at you from a distance to shut them down. The sword combos feel a little clunky sometimes and dont always register the move i pushed in which is a little annoying but nothing gamebreaking. Some enemies have cool extra animations when you kill them a certain way too. The problem with this game? The Camera and sometimes the targeting system. The camera is awful througout most of this game as it locks your view sometimes and makes some attacks come out of nowhere, this is really something that almost broke the game for me the first 30 minutes or so and only my love for the combat made me push on. The targeting is derived somewhat from the Z-targeting of the Zelda series which is an argument in itself, not a fan personally but hey, if you liked the combat in Zelda, you are going to love this game. 4/10 with the camera, it's awful but the game carries it.  The story is really wierd and good. Most characters aren't acting human, just badass. This annoyed me to some extent but since this game is really over the top in all cases it kind of grew on me. It's so bad it's good. I laughed on multiple occasions at the quirky dialogue and the illogical statements of many of the characters. Dante is hands down the best character because he simply doesn't give a f*ck and just enjoys the show. The boss killings with Dante are ten times better too, just play the game and you'll know what I mean. 10/10, it doesn't get any more tacky and cool than this. Although it should be said that this is probably one of the most gender insensitive games I have played, all the girls that actually do anything (that would be like one of them) dress like hookers. Neros girlfriend did eventually talk without screaming "Nero" and thats a step forward I guess. Not that this doesn't fit the title with its tacky characters (especially Dante) it just doesn't sit right with me that all women need to spot cleavage in a game this awesome. So like 4/10 on gender eq in this game.To summerize it is a really good game despite the bad camera and the wierd characters. 												TL; DR: Good game with really fun gameplay and mostly tight controls but that can be a little frustrating at times. Over-the-top fun characters, story and cutscenes. Disappointing lack of additional playable characters.Finally got around to beating this game and I have to say, I'm sorry it took me so long (due to technical bugs corrupting my game saves and such). The gameplay is as strong as it's been in the long-standing franchise, better actually as you get to play as new hero Nero as well as Dante later on in the game. They both play very differently but offer equally compelling modes of fun and over-the-top signature DMC aerial & ground combos mixed with guns but I was partial to Dante's gameplay as I found his ground combos, 4 styles and additional weaponry to offer a lot more versatility and enjoyment. In fact, Dante sports some of the most creative and badass weapons that I've had to joy to play with and for them alone the game is worth getting.But I digress, aside from the incredibly fun, tight and varied combat the game takes you through cool-looking environments typical of the series that are are both grand in scale and that offer neat platforming elements and hidden collectibles/missions that round up the game nicely.However, as it also typical of the franchise there is a fair amount of backtracking as you need to go back and unlock certain areas once you gain the appropriate new ability (which is fine) but this is further compounded by the fact that you revisit the same exact areas when you later play as Dante. I find this to be shame and a sign of the development team cutting corners and saving time & money, but it ultimately cheapens the quality of the game. What's more is that you fight the exact same 3 bosses as Dante that you did as Nero which just feels like a let-down and a missed opportunity to have turned a really good game into a fantastic one.Next, the story. There isn't anything really original about it as it's your standard corrupt organization-turned-zealots-who-try-to-remake-the-world-in-their-image-and-the-hero(s)-have-to-stop-them fare. Despite this I really enjoyed it thanks to the playful & devil-may-care (lawl, see wut I did there? :P) attitudes of both main characters although it's a lot more pronounced and entertaining in Dante's case than it is with Nero. The story is also filled with over-the-top HILARIOUS cutscenes such as a back & forth theatrical soliloquy between Dante and one of the game's bosses that is one of the funniest moments that I've experienced in a game :). Coupled with this are lots of extremely stylish and badass sequences that really help to further set the tone for the game and give you an appreciation for how powerful these characters really are.As for the shortcomings of the game I found the use of fixed camera angles in many locations to be rather frustrating as it's easy to have your character come to a sudden stop or start running in the opposite direction when you enter a new area where the camera angle is different from the previous one. I also felt that 2 of the more difficult moves (for Nero) were overly complicated to perform as they require incredible reflexes and timing which I and I'm sure many other gamers just don't have and so I never really used them. This is in contrast to similiar combo-heavy games like God of War, Bayonetta and Castlevania: Lords of Shadow that have as complicated a move and ability set but where all the controls are accessible and aren't an exercise in frustration.It's also rather unfortunate that despite being able to unlock 2 additional harder modes (and 2 even tougher after that, h.o.l.y.c.r.a.p.!) after having beaten the game there is no further option to play as Trish/Gloria or Lady which is another missed opportunity, Team Ninja :(. I say this because you could unlock Trish and Vergil as playable characters in DMC 2 & 3, respectively.           Furthermore I find it disappointing that the devleopper resorted to over-sexualizing their female characters in order to help sell the game, giving them unrealistic exagerrated curves and bounciness that they didn't possess in previous games in the series. I'm all for sexy models but only when they make sense and aren't objectifying.Finally, I'd be remiss if I didn't mention the game's intrinsic difficulty: the game is HARD (especially on the 2nd default difficulty available at the start) and will kick your♥♥♥♥♥♥and challenge you to play better, which I loved. 												So I'm at the end with Nero now, it's entertaining and keeps things rather interesting combat-wise, but it's not without it's problems. If you enjoy fast-paced hack and slash I'd recommend it, though it's not too fast by default. I'm about to drop some hate on it, but by all means play it, I hate it but love it just enough to keep playing. 6/10Be Aware That:- Enemies can fall through the map, with some luck and gunfire you may lure them back, if not you have to restart.- If you want a challenge this game isn't for you. Every time you lose (to a boss for sure) they'll be handicapped unless you restart the whole level. This is not optional, and is rather insulting. So don't die if you like to brag about beating it on the hardest difficulty, otherwise you'll be bragging that you lost until you ultimately won from all the losing.- DX10 mode will cause crashes durring cutscenes, sometimes before you even realize that one is taking place, causing you to restart.- The camera is your greatest enemy. Forward will become backward and then forward and then backward before you know what's going on. Combt controls also change based on the camera position.- Dante's AI is extremely lame, borderline godly due to faster animations, and also possesses invulnerability frames/animations that will prevent him from being damaged as he slowly does whatever he pleases.
